raw_text:
Aids and climate top Davos agenda
 
 Climate change and the fight against Aids are leading the list of concerns for the first day of the World Economic Forum in the Swiss resort of Davos.
 
 Some 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe will listen to UK Prime Minister Tony Blair's opening speech on Wednesday. Mr Blair will focus on Africa's development plans and global warming. Earlier in the day came an update on efforts to have 3 million people on anti-Aids drugs by the end of 2005. The World Health Organisation (WHO) said 700,000 people in poor countries were on life-extending drugs - up from 440,000 six months earlier but amounting to only 12% of the 5.8 million who needed them. A $2bn "funding gap" still stood in the way of hitting the 2005 target, the WHO said.
 
 The themes to be stressed by Mr Blair - whose attendance was announced at the last minute - are those he wants to dominate the UK's chairmanship of the G8 group of industrialised states. Other issues to be discussed at the five-day conference range from China's
 
 economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. Aside from Mr Blair, more than 20 other world leaders are expected to attend including French President Jacques Chirac - due to speak by video link after bad weather delayed his helicopter - and South African President Thabo Mbeki, whose arrival has been delayed by Ivory Coast peace talks. The Ukraine's new president, Viktor Yushchenko, will also be there - as will newly elected Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas. Showbiz figures will also put in an appearance, from U2 frontman Bono - a well-known campaigner on trade and development issues - to Angelina Jolie, a goodwill campaigner for the UN on refugees.
 
 Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. At the same time, about 100,000 people are expected to converge on the Brazilian resort of Porto Alegre for the World Social Forum - the so-called "anti-Davos" for campaigners against globalisation, for fair trade, and many other causes.
 
 In contrast, the Davos forum is dominated by business issues - from outsourcing to corporate leadership - with bosses of more than a fifth of the world's 500 largest companies scheduled to attend. A survey published on the eve of the conference by PricewaterhouseCoopers said four in ten business leaders were "very confident" that their companies would see sales rise in 2005. Asian and American executives, however, were much more confident than their European counterparts. But the political discussions, focusing on Iran, Iraq and China, are likely to dominate media attention.
llama3.2:1b: UK Prime Minister Tony Blair will address World Economic Forum attendees on Wednesday, including efforts to combat climate change and AIDS.
A $2 billion funding gap remains in place for life-extending AIDS drugs in poor countries, with 700,000 people now on them versus 440,000 six months earlier.
llama3.2:3b: Climate change and AIDS prevention top agenda at Davos conference as 2000 business leaders gather; 700,000 people in poor countries have access to life-extending AIDS drugs but $2bn funding gap remains; Tony Blair addresses the conference with focus on Africa's development plans and global warming; 20 world leaders expected including French President Chirac and newly elected Palestinian leader Abbas; protests are muted as World Social Forum takes place in Brazil.
gemma2:2b: The World Economic Forum in Davos is focused on climate change and the fight against AIDS.
Speakers include UK Prime Minister Tony Blair, French President Jacques Chirac, South African President Thabo Mbeki, and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas, among others.
Business leaders will also attend, with a focus on issues such as outsourcing, corporate leadership, and sales growth.

Protests against the forum are expected to be muted this year, while the World Social Forum, an "anti-Davos" event for campaigners against globalisation, is set to draw around 100,000 people to Porto Alegre.
Political discussions will likely dominate media attention.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The World Economic Forum is set for a major summit with topics like climate change and AIDS control, with world leaders attending Davos in Switzerland.
There are several business leaders who will be present including top figures from the UK, South Africa, and the US.
The forum's focus will be on global issues such as economic power, trade, and development.

Key points:
- World Economic Forum to discuss climate change and AIDS control
- More than 500 world leaders expected to attend Davos in Switzerland
- Business leaders set to speak about topics like outsourcing and corporate leadership
- Topics like economic power, trade, and development will be covered
- Issues related to the G8 group of industrialised states are also likely to be discussed.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Davos meeting focuses on climate change and Aids, with high-level leaders discussing development issues and global warming.
Blair addresses Africa's development plans and HIV/AIDS efforts.
CEO Bono speaks about fair trade and refugee campaigns.
Political discussions on Iran, Iraq, China overshadow business-focused Davos conference.
qwen2.5:3b: Aids and climate change top the agenda for the first day of the World Economic Forum in Davos.
UK Prime Minister Tony Blair will speak about Africa's development plans and global warming.
2 million people across poor countries need anti-Aids drugs but only 12% are currently on them, with a $2 billion funding gap remaining.
Other topics include China’s economic power, Iraq’s future after elections, and the G8 group of industrialised states chaired by the UK.
The forum will feature world leaders such as French President Jacques Chirac, South African President Thabo Mbeki, and newly elected Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas.
While protests are expected to be mild, about 100,000 people will attend the World Social Forum in Porto Alegre instead.
Business issues dominate the conference, with over one-fifth of the world’s largest companies sending representatives.
Sales forecasts predict a 40% confidence boost among business leaders for 2005 sales.
opencoder:1.5b:
Aids and climate change top Davos agenda

Climate change and the fight against Aids are leading concerns for the first day of the World Economic Forum in Switzerland.
UK Prime Minister Tony Blair will focus on Africa's development plans and global warming.
The 3 million people on anti-Aids drugs by the end of 2005 were announced.
The World Health Organisation (WHO) said up from a staggering 440,000 that many in poor countries needed life-extending drugs.
Stressed themes include Mr Blair’s attendance at the last minute and those he wants to dominate UK chairmanship of the G8 group of industrialised states.
Concerns arise from various trade, UN development and other international issues.

Around the world, more than 20 leaders will attend including France's President Jacques Chirac who delayed his helicopter during bad weather, and South Africa's President Thabo Mbeki whose election was delayed by Ivory Coast peace talks.
The new president of Ukraine, Viktor Yushchenko, is there as well.
Also, a prominent speaker on trade and development issues, New York Times frontman Bono, has been there.
In contrast, globalisation issues like global warming and anti-globalisation campaigners have been muted.
Protests against the World Economic Forum are expected to be held but about 100,000 people will converge at the Brazilian resort of Porto Alegre for the World Social Forum.
A survey published on the eve of the conference by PricewaterhouseCoopers revealed that more than half were "very confident" in their companies having seen sales rise.
The political discussions around the world are likely to be dominated, focusing on Iraq and China, while others like Iran focus on international security issues and nuclear strategy.
But these discussions also have the potential to cause major media attention.

tinydolphin:1.1b: The World Economic Forum (WEF), held in Davos, Switzerland every year, is the most influential gathering of global leaders.
This year's summit features a mix of political, business, and social issues.
Key topics include climate change, global warming, and access to affordable healthcare for people around the world.

The event has attracted over 2000 business and political leaders from around the globe, with participation expected from leaders like Tony Blair, French President Jacques Chirac, and South African President Thabo Mbeki.
This year's theme is "The Davos Agenda: People, Planet, Profit," which highlights the interconnectedness of these three areas.
phi:2.7b: The World Economic Forum in Davos will focus on climate change and Aids with UK Prime Minister Tony Blair opening the conference.
There is a $2 billion funding gap for anti-Aids drugs as only 12% of the 5.8 million people who need them have access to life-extending drugs.

Mr Blair also wants to dominate the G8's chairmanship while other issues such as China's economic power and Iraq's future after elections will be discussed at the conference, with U2 frontman Bono and Angelina Jolie expected in attendance.

A $2bn "funding gap" still stood in the way of hitting the 2005 target, the WHO said.
More than 20 other world leaders are expected to attend, including French President Jacques Chirac and South African President Thabo Mbeki, whose arrival has been delayed by Ivory Coast peace talks.
The Ukraine's new president, Viktor Yushchenko, will also be there, as will newly elected Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas.
Showbiz figures will also put in an appearance, from U2 frontman Bono to Angelina Jolie, a goodwill campaigner for the UN on refugees.
Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted but anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, kicked off with climate change and global AIDS as primary concerns for 2,000 business and political leaders.

Notable attendees include Presidents Jacques Chirac (speaking via video link) and Thabo Mbeki, as well as new Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko and newly elected Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas.
Showbiz figures like Bono and Angelina Jolie will participate.
In contrast to past years, anti-globalization protests were called off, while approximately 100,000 activists converged on Porto Alegre for the World Social Forum.

The Davos forum concentrates on business topics such as outsourcing and corporate leadership, with PricewaterhouseCoopers reporting that 40% of business leaders expect sales growth in 2005, particularly from Asian and American executives.
